summary.seg: Cambridge University Library MS Ll.5.18 is a small fifteenth-century miscellany, consisting of a selection of devotional vernacular texts: the final portion of the treatise The Direccion of a Mannys Lyfe, The Life and The Charter of the Abbey of the Holy Ghost, the Life of Saint Dorothy, a translated excerpt from Saint Augustine’s De contemptu mundi and John Lydgate’s Life of Saint Margaret. As such, it can offer us a valuable insight into personal spiritual practices in the late medieval period.

Currently, the provenance of the manuscript remains a matter of supposition. That said, it can be firmly situated among a well-documented manuscript tradition from the period in which miscellanies present female saints’ vitae and/or Marian material along with the Abbey and Charter. British Library MS Harley 5272, for example, bears close textual parallels to MS Ll.5.18, containing both the Abbey and Charter in addition to a verse life of Saint Dorothy and Lydgate’s Life of Our Lady. Drawing upon this, a number of scholars have proposed that these compilations were prepared with a female reader in mind; if this proves true for MS Ll.5.18, it becomes an all the more focused lens into fifteenth-century religious habitudes.

Katherine Dixon
English Faculty
University of Cambridge

msItem.title: The Abbey of the Holy Ghost, etc.
The Direccion of a Mannys Lyfe
msItem.explicit: Explicit | Dexteram scribentis regat virtus omnipotentis

msItem.title: The Abbey of the Holy Ghost
msItem.incipit: This ys the abbey of Seint Sperite that ys founded in a place that ys clepyd conscience
msItem.explicit: Thus endith the abbay of the holy goste of the conscience in whiche ben founded all good vertues and all weked vices of synne drevyn oute et cetera

msItem.title: The Charter of the Abbey of the Holy Ghost
msItem.incipit: Thus begynnethe the place of the abbasse and all the convent and of ther charters and inoueni

msItem.title: The Life of Saint Dorothy
msItem.incipit: Here begynythe the lyff off the holy virgine Seynte dorothea
msItem.explicit: here endethe the lyff off þe holy vergyne Seynt Dorothea
msItem.colophon: Si modo non sensus non clarum ubi auorum | Si probitas magnos Ingenium que facit. [This couplet is taken from Ovid’s Ex Ponto: Book 1, Chapter IX. See Ovid, Tristia & Ex Ponto, ed. and trans. by A. L. Wheeler, 2nd edn, rev. by G. P. Gould (London: Harvard University Press, 1996), p. 312.]

msItem.title: A translated excerpt of Augustine’s De Contemptu Mundi
msItem.colophon: Qui vult vt vnus uti duobus beneficiis | Hic vnus vt duo ardebit in suppliciis. [This seems to paraphrase the Athanasian Creed in its stressing of the unity of the Godhead.]

msItem.title: John Lydgate’s Life of Saint Margaret
msItem.incipit: Here begynythe the lyff off þe holy virgine and martyr seynt margarete
msItem.colophon: Nunc feci all þis pro Christo da mihi seruice | Dum calor est et amena dies formica laborat | Ne pereat cum nix venerit alta fame. [The second two lines are taken from Alain de Lille’s Liber parabolarum. See Alanus de Insulis, ‘Liber Parabolarum’, in Patrologia Latina ed. by J P. Migne, 221 vols (Harvard University Divinity School, 1844-1864), CCX (1855), col. 584. Note that Lille’s text reads ‘pulchra’ where Roger F writes ‘amena’.]

supportDesc.extent: vi + 41 + v; all flyleaves part of modern rebinding. Written height and width varies per page. 207 142

collation.p: There are no conventional catchwords or quire signatures visible in MS Ll.5.18. Having said this, there is equally no explicit evidence to suggest that trimming to remove such inclusions has occurred. Certainly, the retention of the marginalia on f. 36r, in which the final letters are obfuscated by wear rather than trimming, shows that the size of the manuscript cannot have been significantly altered in size since this commentary was added. Although a compilation manuscript, texts regularly run unbroken between quires.

There is a single example of a ‘catchword’ functioning between the recto and verso of a leaf as opposed to between quires on f. 28r. Here, at the centre of the bottom of the page the word ‘Scribe’ appears, distinct from the body of the text. This is the word with which the verso continues. This feature is found elsewhere in homiletic prose and to this end, particularly given the quarto structure of MS Ll.5.18, raises questions regarding the sequence in which pages of a quarto were filled and at which stage the pages were folded and ordered during the writing process. Similarly, it could potentially indicate the scribe offering himself an aide-memoire during the copying process, noting where to commence upon return to the manuscript.
There is no evidence of pricking or ruling in MS Ll.5.18 and lines are written in free-hand throughout.

supportDesc.condition: The manuscript is generally of a good condition. The leaf height and width offered above is, however, an average measurement. Due to both rough-trimming in the first instance and subsequent wear over time the edges of pages are particularly worn (with some minor interventional repairs). The size of each folio therefore varies slightly from one to the next.

layoutDesc.layout: The writing area on each page varies not only between texts or quires but often from folium to folium, augmenting the sense of a semi-spontaneous production. As a general rule, the scribe is conscious to leave conventional margins (generally in excess of an inch) to the top, bottom and inside of each page (and particularly after the first quire) however, in prose, he often allows lines to run to the very edge of the paper.

handDesc.p: The majority of the text is self-referentially attributed to the same scribe ‘Roger F’, discussed in more detail below. He writes in a mixed or hybrid script throughout, combining elements of Anglicana Formata and Current Secretary hands.

The scribe uses the capital short-s form that is adopted from university hands and the lowercase ‘d’ grapheme that is, although still somewhat looped, more upright than its predecessors. The ‘2’-shaped ‘r’ and angular ‘o’ are also present. The highly identifiable double compartment ‘a’ is also used frequently. Two lowercase ‘e’ allographs are present: both the reverse ductus ‘e’ and horned ‘e’ grapheme. Almost always, the scribe loops ascenders, particularly for ‘b’, ‘h’ and ‘l’, however he shows less of a preponderance to do so on the first line of a page where he frequently only partially loops them. A cursive ‘m’, produced in a single pen stroke, appears far more consistently than its Anglicana Formata form, for which each minim is formed separately.

The scribe also adopts the horned form of ‘g’ as opposed to the closed-compartment ‘g’. Similarly, the Secretary single compartment ‘a’ and simpler ‘w’ form also occur mixed among their corresponding Anglicana Formata forms throughout. See for example ‘margarete’ on f. 33r in which both ‘a’ allographs appear.
Notably, the only example of the dotted ‘y’ grapheme occurs in the first treatise fragment.

The ductus of the scribe is predominantly of a vertical aspect with the stems and tails of most graphemes extending to approximately twice the height of the main line of writing. The scribe shows a propensity to slant to the right in some parts of the manuscript, perhaps an indication of the haste of composition at times. This also reflects the influence of the Secretary script on the hand. Otiose strokes are equally as present in either instance. The hand is highly cursive and ligatures are used frequently but idiosyncratically, the same is true of approach and end strokes.
The titles of the Life of Saint Dorothy and Life of Saint Margaret are far larger than the main script, serving a decorative function, and are in a mixed Bastard Anglicana and Bastard Secretary hand.

A characteristic feature of Roger F’s style is his inclusion of a brief Latin colophon at the end of each vernacular text. This is always in a distinctly different and more formal hand from his main script: Neat Secretary following the majority and Anglicana Formata following the Life of Saint Margaret.

While this is a compilation manuscript, the main mixed hand it relatively consistent throughout. There is one notable exception to this on the final leaf of the final text in the manuscript: Lygate’s Life of Saint Margaret. Throughout the verse, the scribe maintains a design of three stanzas to the page, however two-thirds of the way down f. 41r the handwriting changes to a distinct Secretary Hand of a much smaller aspect but taking up no less space. This is the opposite of an example offered by Malcolm Parkes, in which he illustrates the ‘degradation’ of a mid-fifteenth century hand that increases in cursivity as the manuscript progresses, moving from Current Secretary to a mixed script. See Parkes, English Cursive Book Hands: 1350 – 1550 (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1969), pp. 21-22.
A seventeenth-century hand, writing in abbreviated Latin, appears on the bottom of f. 29r.

Scribal attribution: Ian Doyle attributes this manuscript to the ‘amateurish hand of Roger F’. His signature appears at the end of each text with the exception of the first incomplete treatise excerpt. He adds ‘per Roger R F’ following the final prayer that ends The Abbey of the Holy Ghost and The Charter of the Abbey of the Holy Ghost (that appear to have been copied in a single instance as the copying bridges two quires and occurs in identical ink and with the same mise-en-page) on f. 24v. The Life of Saint Dorothy ends with ‘Roger F’ (f. 28v) and the Augustine excerpt with ‘per R F’ (f. 29r). The manuscript ends with a brief prayer following Lydgate’s Life of Saint Margaret. It finishes ‘Amen per F’ (f. 41v).

The A Catalogue of the Manuscripts Preserved in the Library of the University of Cambridge identifies a brief addition in the hand of Thomas Tanner (d. 1735) who catalogues this manuscript in his Bibliotheca Britannico-Hibernica (published in 1748) under Lydgate as ‘MS. Norwic. More. 191’. MS Ll.5.18 came to Cambridge University Library through the Bishop Moore bequest and a bookplate dated to 1715 from the Moore collection has been preserved in the re-binding process. Tanner was private chaplain to Bishop John Moore of Norwich during his early career. It is presumably for these reasons that the Catalogue deduces that the addition ‘by John Lydgate Monk of Bury’ on f. 29v to the originally unattributed Life of Saint Margaret, which begins on this page, was inserted by Tanner.
Punctuation: Punctuation occurs only in the form of the raised punctus in both the prose and verse material. In Lydgate’s Life of Saint Margaret stanzas are marked with a flat topped ‘u’ grapheme.
Abbreviation: The abbreviation schema throughout the manuscript is standard in both the vernacular and the Latin.

Abbreviation generally takes the form of superscription (such as wt and þt) although the scribe employs these erratically, often electing to use the unabbreviated word form regardless of issues such as space.

The scribe also frequently uses typical indicators of contraction such as a looped superscript flourish extending from the preceding grapheme to indicate an ‘m’ or ‘n’ (e.g. ‘omnipotentis’ on f. 1r) or similarly on the word final letter to indicate an absent penultimate ‘m’ or ‘n’ such as in the case of ‘oyntment’ on f. 25v. Similarly, the scribe consistently abbreviates er/ar/ir/ur/or/ro following m, v and p as in the examples of ‘mercy’ (f. 1r), virgyne (f. 25r) and persecucon (f. 25r) or pereat (f. 41v). As above, abbreviations following both ‘m’ and ‘v’ are indicated with a flourish extending from the grapheme whereas an abbreviation following ‘p’ is typically marked by crossing the descender of the letter form. Bar suspension indicating a word final 'm' in Ingenium on f. 28v. Bar suspension is also used to indicate an absent 'i' in tion/cion constructions.

decoDesc.decoNote: No illumination, illustration or rubrication occurs in MS Ll.5.18. Larger, more decorative handwriting with otiose strokes and additional flourishes is adopted for the titles of the two saints’ lives (f. 25r and f. 29v) and far more significantly in the case of the Lydgate. The scribe also shows a greater preponderance for otiose strokes in the verse. Underlining of occasional passages throughout.

At the end of the Dirrection of a Mannys Life (f. 1r), The Charter of the Abbey of the Holy Ghost (f. 24v) and the Augustine excerpt (f. 29r) one sees the same practice of filling the end of a line of prose with a distinctive decorative ‘AMEN’. In each instance, this sequence is identical, consisting of each letter capitalised and separated by a decorative marking made up of a tilde stroke intersected by one or two vertical lines. The fact that this distinctive trait is present at the end of the first excerpt may evidence the fact that the same scribe copied the now largely lost first text as part of the surviving manuscript segment as opposed to repurposing a half-used quire to commence this compilation work. This practice is in contrast to the purely decorative line-filling that appears on f. 18r.

additions.p: Marginalia: There is a single example of marginalia in MS Ll.5.18 on f. 36r, where the phrase ‘moyses famulus domini’ appears in the top right-hand corner. This corresponds to the beginning of Joshua 22.2 and is also the name of a popular chant inspired by the Biblical passage that was frequently allocated to the Feast of Dom. 4 Quadragesimae. There appears to be no connection between this notation and the Lydgate stanzas to which it is adjacent and, thus, is likely an example of pen practice.

Corrections: There are very few corrections in this manuscript. The few cases of correction seem to occur in the same hand and ink immediately following the error. For example, on f. 2v the scribe simply scribbles out ‘That’ before continuing the prose and similarly does so for ‘yf’ on f. 25v.

The scribe also employs the corrective methods of insertion and superscription. On f. 6v there is an example of the word ‘white’ being added by means of a circumflex between letters. More commonly, however, the scribe simply superscripts the missing letter over the place of omission (e.g. senato˹r˺es on f. 25r). Due to the scribe’s application of superscription both when correcting and abbreviating words, it is occasionally unclear which task is in action. This is particularly true where only one letter is superscripted when there has been an omission of several letters, as is the case on f. 26r where the scribe writes: ‘dist˹o˺ye’. The word fits best semantically as ‘dist(r)˹o˺ye’, however the superscription does not clearly denote this and is not a common abbreviation notation for ‘ro’. It could thus be equally viewed to serve as an idiosyncratic abbreviation or to fulfil a corrective function. This is particularly so given that two words later ‘torment’ is represented as ‘to˹r˺ment’ where one or both functions are in operation simultaneously. In this instance, the word is not shortened in terms of the number of letters that appear if the superscript ‘r’ is viewed as an abbreviation, it does however abbreviate in the sense that it condenses the physical length of the word on the page.

On f. 25r correction has occurred through scraping between ‘god’ and ‘with’ and this has thinned the paper beyond use on the verso. This indicates that the correction happened immediately in the writing process, rather than during a process of checking and revision.

Additions: A strip of paper was pasted over the bottom quarter of f. 29r, although has since become loose revealing that which it covered. The material that has been covered is inverted and consists of three lines of writing and a signature. The writing fragment has been cut through to form the correct dimensions for the quarto. The paper that has been used to cover this is also scrap material being re-utilised, with writing covering its entirety and truncated by trimming on its outer and bottom edges. This suggests that the strip was cut specifically to fit the space it was required to cover. F. 29r appears mid-quire, however it marks the beginning of the excerpt taken from Augustine, which finishes well in advance of the material that required covering. The writing that follows the excerpt is a Latin couplet, with a matching (in both hand and form) Latin couplet occurring adjacently, and then a short piece of Latin writing in a separate hand and ink. The latter piece of writing, written in a seventeenth century hand, flows directly from the original page and onto the paste-over.

bindingDesc.p: The binding is modern and of paper boards, completed by Douglas Cockerell & Son in 1970. There is also internal evidence for this preservation as worm holes within the manuscript have become misaligned as a result of the re-binding.

origin.origDate: Fifteenth century. This is ratified by the dateable texts contained in MS Ll.5.18, which accommodate production from quite early in the first half of the century. The Life of Saint Margaret, commissioned by Edmund Mortimer, was composed by John Lydgate between 1415-26 and the version of the Life of Saint Dorothy contained in MS Ll.5.18 has been identified by Manfred Görlach to be one of a group of the tale that dates from the early fifteenth century.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on unpublished manuscript notes by M. R. James. I also am grateful to Richard Beadle for his advice regarding the provenance of the manuscript, which remains a work in progress.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card for admissions procedures contact Cambridge University Library Admissions). Contact the Manuscripts Department for further information on the availability of this manuscript
